awd_titl_txt: High-Level Coupled-Cluster Energetics by Monte Carlo Sampling and Moment Expansions
awd_abstract_narration:
Piotr Piecuch of Michigan State University is supported by an award from the Chemical Theory, Models and Computational Methods program in the Chemistry Division to develop a radically new approach to solving the many-particle Schrodinger equation.   This method holds the key to explaining the motion of electrons in atoms and molecules. By understanding the details of this motion, Piecuch and his group can precisely determine the amounts of energy needed to break chemical bonds and transform reactants into products.  The ability to do these calculations accurately will ultimately aid in the design of new materials, better catalysts, and more efficient energy sources. The new approach uses repeated random tests of many small energy contributions and retains those found to be most important. This approach reduces the computational costs of high-accuracy methods by orders of magnitude. Once fully developed, the methods will be shared with the community via open-source mechanisms. Findings resulting from the activities are being used in teaching courses and communicated through publications, seminars, and conference presentations. These ideas provide positive training experiences in the forefront of the physical sciences for members of the Piecuch group. 

This research addresses one of the key challenges in electronic structure theory, namely the development of practical and systematically improvable ab initio computational schemes aimed at an accurate description of molecular energetics. It is widely accepted that size extensive methods based on the coupled-cluster theory are excellent candidates for addressing this challenge. However, it has been notoriously difficult to incorporate higher-than two-body components of the cluster operator, needed to achieve a quantitative description, without running into prohibitive computational costs of higher-order coupled-cluster schemes. The proposed methodology solves the problem, allowing one to obtain accurate energetics equivalent to high-level coupled-cluster calculations, even when electronic quasi-degeneracies and higher-than pair excitations become significant, at a small fraction of the computational cost. It also preserves the black-box character of conventional single-reference computations, by fusing the deterministic formalism, abbreviated as CC(P;Q) with the stochastic configuration interaction and coupled-cluster Monte Carlo approaches. The formal and algorithmic advances and efficient computer implementations will be accompanied by calculations of molecular potential energy surfaces relevant to spectroscopy, chemical reaction mechanisms and dynamics, and catalysis. The work provides important training for graduate students and postdoctoral fellows and the programs being developed will be widely shared with the broader theoretical community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
One of the goals of quantum chemistry is to precisely describe increasingly complex polyatomic systems and molecular potential energy surfaces. It is generally accepted that size-extensive coupled-cluster (CC) methods and their extensions to open-shell and excited states, which in the majority of applications relevant to chemical reactivity, spectroscopy, and photochemistry rapidly converge to the exact, full configuration interaction (CI) limit, are excellent candidates for addressing this goal, but it has been difficult to incorporate higher-than-two-body components of the cluster and excitation operators, needed to achieve a quantitative description, in a robust manner, without running into prohibitive computational costs of the full CCSDT, full CCSDTQ, and similar schemes and failures of the more practical approximations of the CCSD(T), CCSD(TQ), etc. types in multi-reference situations involving significant bond rearrangements, biradicals, and excited states dominated by two-electron transitions.

This project addressed the above difficulties by developing, implementing, and testing a radically new way of obtaining high-level CC energetics of the CCSDT, CCSDTQ, and similar types, even when multi-reference correlation effects become significant, at the small fraction of the computational cost and preserving the black-box character (minimum input informaion) of conventional single-reference computations, by merging the deterministic formalism, abbreviated as CC(P;Q), with the stochastic CI and CC Quantum Monte Carlo (QMC) propagations in the many-electron Hilbert space. The PI and graduate students and postdocs working on the project have generated substantial evidence that the resulting semi-stochastic CC(P;Q) methodology, which uses CIQMC or CCMC runs to identify the leading Slater determinants or the dominant types of cluster amplitudes and the suitably designed a posteriori energy corrections to capture the remaining electron correlations of interest, enables rapid convergence toward the target high-level CC electronic energetics based on the information extracted from the early stages of the relevant QMC propagations. The advantages of the new CIQMC- and CCMC-driven CC(P;Q) methodologies and their underlying CC(P) counterparts were illustrated by applications to chemical bond dissociations and reaction pathways, singlet-triplet gaps in biradical systems, and open-shell and excited states, including those having a substantial multi-reference character. The semi-stochastic CC(P) and CC(P;Q) methods and computer codes and their deterministic counterparts developed in the project can utilize modern parallel computer architectures and are well suited for adopting novel or state-of-the-art programming strategies, such as automated implementations.

Intellectual Merit. They key idea of the project, in which the stochastic QMC propagations in the many-electron Hilbert space are used to identify the most important components of the electronic wave function and the deterministic CC computations calculate these important components, while correcting for the rest of the information about the many-electron correlation effects of interest, opens up a new research paradigm in quantum chemistry, and many-body theory in general. The semi-stochastic CC(P) and CC(P;Q) methods and computer codes developed and implemented in the project address some of the most important challenges of modern electronic structure theory, which are the development of practical and systematically improvable computational schemes that can provide a balanced and accurate description of closed- and open-shell systems, rapidly changing many-electron correlation effects along chemical reaction coordinates, and molecular electronic energetics, and the development of novel algorithms that can reduce very high, often prohibitive, costs of high-accuracy ab initio CC calculations with a full treatment of higher-than-two-body cluster and excitation operators.

Broader impacts. The theoretical methods and computer codes developed in the project enable precise modeling of molecular processes and properties relevant to chemical reactivity, spectroscopy, and photochemistry. The methodological advances made in the project have been and will continue to be shared with the community via established open-source mechanisms, including interfacing the resulting computer codes with the GAMESS and PSI4 packages and making them available on GitHub. They have been accompanied by numerous useful benchmark calculations, where comparisons have been made with the exact, full CI, and nearly exact CCSDT, CCSDTQ, and other high-accuracy data. The new methods and computer codes developed in the project have already found use in molecular applications discussed by the PI and co-workers in publications, and they will continue to be used in new applications, including those beyond the scope of the project, in the future work. Findings resulting from the project have been and will continue to be used in graduate courses, seminars, and conference and workshop presentations (some available on the internet, including the PI's research group website and YouTube). The project provided excellent training experiences in the forefront physical sciences for student and postdoctoral members of the PI's group. Three of the five graduate students participating in the project were awarded doctoral degrees and have started pursuing their postdoctoral careers afterwards.
